awd_abstract_narration:
The kinetic theory on rarefied particles have played an important role in the understanding of problems in gas dynamics, plasma physics, and fluid equations.  In many physical situations (for example, plasma in tokamak fusion reactor), the particles interact with boundaries and their interaction affects global dynamics significantly.  Singular behavior of particle distribution near the boundary is major difficulty in both mathematical understanding and the experiment.  This project aims to develop new mathematical tools to handle these problems and answer several fundamental questions. 

This research project studies several important boundary problems arising in kinetic models and fluid equations.  In particular, the PI plans to study regularity property of the Vlasov-Maxwell-Boltzmann system with boundary conditions.  The equation is nonlinear, nonlocal, and degenerated dissipative coupled with hyperbolic equation (wave equation).  Due to the characteristics boundary condition, the solutions are singular in general.  Successful investigations for the proposal would mark a significant development in the PDE theory with singularity.  Results of the project are expected to improve modeling capabilities for a wide range of problems of interest to other scientists and engineers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The kinetic theory of rarefied particles plays a crucial role in understanding issues in gas dynamics, plasma physics, and fluid equations. In many physical scenarios, such as the plasma in a Tokamak fusion reactor, particle interactions with boundaries significantly affect global dynamics. The singular behavior of particle distributions near these boundaries presents a major challenge both mathematically and experimentally. In this project, the principal investigator has developed new mathematical tools to address these issues and answer several fundamental questions. The outcomes of this research aim to advance the understanding of these and other critical systems. In conjunction with the research, the investigator is developing graduate-level courses, undergraduate directed study courses, research activities for undergraduate students, and workshops for practicing mathematicians.

This research project focuses on several important boundary problems arising in kinetic models and fluid equations. Specifically, the PI plans to study the regularity properties of the Vlasov-Maxwell-Boltzmann system under boundary conditions. This equation is nonlinear, nonlocal, and exhibits degenerate dissipative behavior, coupled with a hyperbolic equation (the wave equation). Due to the nature of the boundary conditions, the solutions tend to be singular. Successful investigations into this proposal would represent a significant advancement in the theory of partial differential equations (PDEs) dealing with singularities. The results are expected to enhance modeling capabilities for a broad range of problems that interest scientists and engineers. One of the fundamental questions in the field of partial differential equations is the development of a unified theory of gas dynamics that connects the mesoscopic Boltzmann equations to macroscopic fluid models (hydrodynamic limits) that arise in formal limits. In this project, the investigator and collaborators rigorously explore the passage mathematically in various physical situations.
